Award.AwardTitle: Multimodal Intergration in a Decision-Making Neuron
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most animals take advantage of multiple information sources to form a coherent percept of the world for adaptive behavioral decisions. These processes occur in complex neural networks embedded in the central nervous system that are typically difficult to identify and to study at the cellular level. Accordingly, a full understanding of the principles underlying multimodal information processing and decision-making has lagged behind. This project aims to significantly extend our understanding of single neurons and their roles in central computation. Specifically, it will address a common yet little understood sensorimotor integration phenomenon: how neurons process multimodal sensory inputs with different temporal characteristics, for example, gradual visual motion stimuli and abrupt sounds. For this purpose, the networks that mediate the fish startle-escape behavior will be used. These networks are unique, because they involve definable decision-making neurons, the Mauthner cells, which receive multimodal inputs and can be studied with electrophysiological and behavioral techniques. A guiding idea for the proposal is that the timing and balance of neural excitation and inhibition play a significant role in information processing and the expression of behavior. These characteristics are directly relevant to nervous system disorders in which this balance is impaired. The multidisciplinary components of this project allow the involvement of students at different levels of training and experience and thus will provide outstanding educational and outreach opportunities. The generation of preliminary results already has involved high school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students.

Multimodal integration enhances our perception when the signal from a single sense organ is weak or deprived. Elucidating the principles and mechanisms by which different senses interact will be very useful in designing/optimizing the sensory environment of people or machines performing perceptually demanding tasks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the project was to understand the mechanisms and principles that underlie the processing of sensory information at the level of individual neurons and their dendrites. Moreover, our focus was on naturalistic stimuli because it has become increasingly clear that neural processing is optimized for such stimuli. For this purpose, we used a well-characterized vertebrate model system, the network that mediates the startle-escape in fish. This network is centered on a pair of large decision-making neurons, the Mauthner (M)-cells, which integrate information from multiple sense organs. Importantly, these neurons allow recording synaptic responses to sensory stimuli with electrophysiological techniques, in vivo. This experimentally accessibility allowed us to reveal the principles and mechanisms by which various inhibitory circuits mediate sensory gating (filtering) in M-cell dendrites. Specifically we showed that parallel and sequential activation of several distinct inhibitory feed forward networks determine the effectiveness of a sensory signal to evoke a behavioral response. This kind of sensorimotor gating is believed to regulate sensory flow during early stages of information processing. Indeed, the CNS has to filter the overwhelming stream of information provided by the various sense organs while optimizing detection of behaviorally relevant information. Given that multiple information processing disorders have been associated with deficits in sensorimotor gating underlines the potential broader significance of our results.

We also elucidated the effector mechanism by which information processing in the M-cell is modulated by the specific serotonin receptor subtype 5-HT5A. We believe these results will be of broad interest, since they provide one of the first functional description of this 5-HT receptor subtype, which is widely expressed in the vertebrate CNS.

Perception typically involves information from different sense organs and processing of multimodal information is essential to an organism’s capacity to respond to environmental events. In fish this involves visually tracking an approaching bird predator that breaks the water surface i.e., visual and auditory sensory information with very different temporal characteristics. How do neurons process such differential sensory inputs at the dendritic level? To address this question we used a combination of neuromorphology, electrophysiology, and computational modeling to study the role of dendritic properties in processing such different sensory information. Overall, our results suggest modality-dependent membrane specializations in neighboring M-cell dendrites, which are well suited for processing stimuli of different temporal characteristics. We also described cross-modal dendritic interactions in M-cell dendrites via back propagating postsynaptic potentials. These findings represent a rare and compelling example for information processing in a single neuron.

Recent research attributes processing power to single neurons and dendrites (e.g., logical operations, multiplications, supra-linear summation) which goes beyond their classical role as passive integrators. However, demonstrating such added functionality has proven difficult. As such, our work provides an important step forward to accomplish this challenge since it defines the biophysical mechanisms underlying such computations in an intact animal and with naturalistic stimuli. Second, the stimuli we use, visual motion and sound clicks, are psychophysical stimuli frequently used to study multimodal integration in the superior colliculus nucleus of other animals, including humans. Indeed, multimodal integration can enhance perception when a signal from one sense organ is weak or deprived. Thus elucidating the principles and mechanisms by which different senses interact might proof very useful in designing/optimizing the sensory environment of people performing perceptually demanding tasks, including individuals with sensory disabilities.

Finally, the physiological, anatomical, behavioral and computational components of this project allowed the involvement of students at different levels of training and experience and thus provided an outstanding educational and outreach opportunities. In fact, the generation of our results over the entire funding period involved numerous undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students. Moreover, during the summers we also included students from several local High Schools as well as from the Harlem Children Society. The latter is an organization promoting science education for under-resourced and under-served communities and school districts. The goal here is to introduce students to science and to encourage them to pursue graduate study in research.
